I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Promoting the availability and use of clean energy is one of the highest priorities of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB). In 2010, ADB funded nearly $1.76 billion worth of projects with 
clean-energy components, exceeding its $1 billion target for the third year in a row. From 2013, 
this target will increase to $2 billion a year. The Asia and Pacific region, where demand for 
energy is projected to almost double by 2030, could start using clean power from sustainable 
solar energy and other renewable sources within the next 3 years.  
 
2.  In May 2010, ADB announced its Asia Solar Energy Initiative. From 2010 to 2012 it will 
finance 3,000 megawatts (MW) of solar power generation projects to (i) keep the region abreast 
of technological developments in solar energy, (ii) identify and develop large-capacity solar 
projects, and (iii) design incentives and innovative financing for the rapid diffusion of solar 
technology for both grid-connected and distributed stand-alone power generation.  
 
3.  As  of  31 January 2011,  coal-fueled  power  plants  accounted  for  54.4%  of  India’s 
generation capacity of 170,000 MW. Renewable energy sources (wind, small hydro, biogas, etc. 
plus a negligible amount of solar-grid-connected power) contributed only about 16,787 MW, or a 
little  less  than  10%  of  the  total.1 India  has  4–7 kilowatt-hours  per  square  meter  of  solar 
irradiation per day with better-than-average irradiation in its western and southeastern regions. 
Recognizing the country’s solar power potential and the possibility of strengthening energy 
security with that renewable resource, the Expert Committee Report on the Integrated Energy 
Policy of the Government of India (adopted in 2008) recommended that a technology mission be 
formed to make solar power more economically attractive. The Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar 
Mission (JNNSM) was launched by the government in January 2010 to promote research and 
development and technology transfer, and to look into the establishment of knowledge hubs for 
solar energy and smart-grid development. With support from the JNNSM, India is expected to 
develop  1,000–2,000 MW  of  utility  grid  power  by  2013,  4,000–10,000 MW  by  2017,  and 
20,000 MW by 2022. Off-grid solar applications of up to 200 MW are also foreseen by 2013, 
1,000 MW by 2017, and 2,000 MW by 2022. The South Asia Department of ADB is backing a 
proposed loan to the state government of Gujarat for the evacuation of power from the 580 MW 
Charankha solar park, the first phase of the solar program. The Private Sector Operations 
Department of ADB will provide a partial credit guarantee for lenders to solar projects, and direct 
loans where possible. 
 
4.  In pursuit of the goals set by the JNNSM, the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT)– 
Rajasthan at Jodhpur has proposed the establishment of the International Center for Application 
of Solar Energy Technologies (ICASET) to carry out research and development in and deploy 
solar energy technologies, benchmark technologies, and develop human resources in the area 
of solar energy. At the same time, other knowledge institutions are developing and expanding 
their capacity development and technology transfer functions to mainstream solar power and 
smart-grid development. In this regard, technical assistance (TA) for the establishment and 
operation of ICASET and other agencies, such as the government of Gujarat, is proposed to 
support the JNNSM.2 
                                                 
1  Information available from the Central Electricity Authority of India. 
2   The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 March 2011.

2   
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Solar energy is regarded as one of the fastest-growing electricity technologies in recent 
years. Improvements in technology, cost structure, enabling policies, and regulatory frameworks 
have driven its spectacular growth in developed countries. Solar energy has many implications 
also for developing member countries (DMCs) in Asia and the Pacific because (i) economies of 
scale can reduce costs to make solar energy competitive with conventional energy resources; 
(ii) some DMCs have greater solar radiation, more rapid growth in electricity demand, and more 
available land than developed countries; and (iii) some DMCs have the potential to become 
global and regional manufacturing hubs for solar technology goods and equipment. 
 
6.  However, the private sector tends to perceive this market as high risk for the following 
reasons,  among  others:  (i) limited  capacity  in  the  DMCs  to  formulate  and  implement  a 
sustainable  policy  and  regulatory  framework  for  solar  power,  (ii) uncertainty  in  adapting 
developed-country technologies to meet DMC needs, and (iii) lack of reliable and innovative 
financing. Technology transfer and development of stakeholder capacity in line with JNNSM 
efforts should settle these misgivings.  
 
7.  Strategy 20203 calls for knowledge solutions that will leverage ADB’s central position in 
identifying trends across the region, its interdisciplinary and integrated approach to assistance, 
and  its  capacity  to  implement  insights  and  knowledge  with  significant  financing  support. 
Together, ADB and its development partners can facilitate technology transfer and knowledge 
sharing  to  create  an  enabling  environment  for  solar  power  development.  As  a  regional 
knowledge institution, ADB is mandated to (i) support pilot projects from which lessons can be 
distilled and disseminated, and (ii) distribute knowledge in ways that have both immediate 
impact  and  catalytic  force.  The  support  provided  is  expected  to  mainstream  solar  power 
development, successfully demonstrate the utility of solar energy in power generation and other 
applications and ease its progress toward eventual parity with other energy sources, and result 
in the development of relevant energy applications in remote areas.  
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
8.  This  proposed  capacity  development  TA  will  help  develop  capacity  and  transfer 
technology to mainstream solar energy and stable grid development in line with the JNNSM. In 
particular, the TA will help IIT–Rajasthan and other agencies, e.g., the state government of 
Gujarat,  to  institutionalize  and  operationalize  solar  energy  and  smart-grid  development 
functions.  It  will  support  knowledge  institutions  in  capacity  development,  research  and 
development, technology transfer and deployment, knowledge sharing, and pilot testing in solar 
thermal and solar photovoltaic energy, hybrid solar energy, smart grids, and thermal-to-cooling 
and thermal-to-thermal technologies. The TA complements the recently approved ADB TA for 
Capacity Building for Commercial Bank Lending for Solar Energy Projects in India.4

A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The expected impact of the TA will be strengthened and more environmentally sound 
energy  security  through  solar  energy  use  and  stable  grid  development  for  inclusive  and 
low-carbon growth in India. The expected outcome will be developed capacity in the country for 
policy, technology, and financing to promote solar energy and stable grid development. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will assist IIT–Rajasthan in establishing and operating ICASET and support the 
Gujarat government and its agencies. The agencies are expected to contribute to (i) reducing 
the capital equipment cost of solar power development and suitably address project risks to 
lower project financing cost, (ii) accelerating the deployment of solar power technology through 
wider  use  of  sub-technologies  for  the  manufacture  of  solar  power  plant  components  and 
balance  of  plant  components,  (iii) adapting  solar  power  technology  to  local  conditions, 
(iv) developing  many  more  innovative  and  value-added  applications  of  solar  energy,  and 
(v) empowering businesses to develop technologies and manufacture critical solar power plant 
components. The output and activities of the TA will be as discussed briefly below. 
 
11.  Establishment of ICASET and research and development capability in Gujarat. The 
TA will assist IIT–Rajasthan in establishing an international knowledge center, ICASET, and the 
Gujarat government in promoting the development of stable and reliable solar parks in the state, 
among other things. The work related to the establishment of ICASET will involve refining the 
draft master plan; preparing the documentation required for government clearance; consulting 
with various stakeholders; coordinating with donor agencies; and developing a work program, a 
budget framework, and a financing plan. 
 
12.  Technology  transfer  and  deployment.  The  TA  will  assist  IIT–Rajasthan  and  the 
Gujarat government in (i) pilot-testing and standardizing solar thermal and solar photovoltaic 
component and plant technologies for solar power generation and deployment; (ii) conducting 
solar resource assessment and environmental testing in Rajasthan for ICASET, and in other 
parts of South Asia; (iii) conducting due diligence on a 1 MW photovoltaic plant using different 
technologies, i.e., single-crystalline, polycrystalline, thin-film, and multilayer solar cells, for an 
optimum mix of mature and emerging technologies for training and research; (iv) developing 
criteria  for  the  selection  of  the  technology  provider;  (v) drafting  the  agreement  with  the 
technology provider; and (vi) assessing grid connectivity and regulatory issues and listing the 
government approvals that must be obtained for a new solar plant. 
 
13.  The technology transfer will center on (i) thermal storage materials; (ii) heat exchanger 
design; (iii) solar photovoltaic systems; (iv) smart grids, including direct-current micro-grids and 
battery storage systems; (v) hybrid technologies; and (vi) innovative, value-added applications 
of solar energy such as solar air-conditioning, solar materials and chemical processing, and 
water purification. An important aspect of developing the solar energy market in Asia and Pacific 
will be the benchmarking of different technologies, i.e., single-crystalline silicon, polycrystalline 
silicon, thin-film, and multilayer solar photovoltaic cells, as well as parabolic troughs, Fresnel 
reflectors,  central  receivers,  and  parabolic  dishes  for  solar  thermal  energy.  To  enable 
benchmarking, the establishment of a megawatt-scale solar plant using different technologies is 
proposed. ICASET plans to procure and install suitable monitoring, analytical, and evaluation 
equipment  (hardware  and  software)  with  resources  mobilized  through  public–private 
partnership. The TA will assist ICASET and the Gujarat government in these activities. The

4   
facilities to be developed by ICASET and the other agencies will be integrated with a smart 
alternating-current power system and a direct-current micro grid for demonstration, and the 
power generated will be supplied to the grid. The consultants will support ICASET in developing 
and operating the plant. 
 
14.  Capacity  development.  The  TA  will  assist  ICASET  and  the  other  agencies  in 
developing and implementing a capacity development program for various stakeholders in India, 
including (i) state governments, (ii) regulators, (iii) power utilities, (iv) the local private sector, 
and (v) other stakeholders. Human resources exchange programs for professors, researchers, 
and students with universities, research institutes, and the private sector in developed countries 
will be developed and carried out in collaboration with ADB and other development partners. A 
capacity development program will also be planned for other countries in South Asia. The 
consultants will assist ICASET and the Gujarat government in facilitating such partnerships.  
 
15.  Knowledge dissemination and business model development. The TA will assist 
ICASET and the other agencies in disseminating knowledge on the outcome of the research 
and  pilot-testing  among  the  various  stakeholders,  and  in  providing  a  business  model  and 
sharing it with the relevant agencies and the private sector. These activities will be done in close 
collaboration with the Asia Solar Energy Forum. The workshops for knowledge sharing will be 
held in India and abroad. For business model development, the consultants will provide partners 
with (i) customized solutions for grid or off-grid solar power generation and distribution, and 
industrial  applications  of  concentrated  solar  power;  (ii) joint  testing,  calibration,  and 
benchmarking of new and existing technologies; (iii) commercial evaluation of technologies, and 
feasibility  and  detailed  engineering  project  reports  for  new  solar  power  projects;  and 
(iv) technical and financial audit of solar power plants. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $2,400,000 equivalent, of which $2,000,000 will 
be financed with a grant from the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction administered by ADB. The 
Government  of  India  will  finance  (in  kind)  the  remaining  $400,000  equivalent.  The  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  IIT–Rajasthan (for ICASET) and the government of Gujarat (for operations in the state of 
Gujarat) will be the executing agencies. The project implementation period is expected to be 18 
months. As envisaged, 25 person-months of consulting services by six international consultants 
and 60 person-months of consulting services by four national consultants will be required. All 
the consultants will be individually recruited, as it may be difficult or even impossible to source 
the broad range of required specializations from a single firm. ADB will recruit consultants 
according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  conform  to  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
18.  Equipment will be procured under the TA funds by ADB according to its Procurement 
Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  An  advance  payment  facility,  to  be 
replenished on liquidation, will be used to disburse funds to cover administrative and operating 
costs.  IIT–Rajasthan and  the state  government  will  be required  to  maintain  operation  and 
administration accounts, to have these accounts audited annually, and to report the results of

5
the annual audit to ADB. To facilitate the timely flow of funds and to reduce the administrative 
burden, IIT–Rajasthan and the state government will be provided with a budget for travel 
expenses under the advance payment facility, to be liquidated monthly. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
19.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $2,000,000 to  the  Government  of  India to  be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for the Development of the 
International Center for Application of Solar Energy Technologies.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of six international consultants 
and four national consultants.  
B.  Scope of Work 
2.  The  consultants  should  have  (i) extensive  experience  in  and  knowledge  of  the 
institutional and commercial aspects of the development of solar or other renewable energy 
parks; (ii) suitable knowledge of renewable energy development in India; and (iii) familiarity with 
the policy, guidelines, and operation manuals of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The 
consultants should have extensively consulted with the relevant stakeholders, including the 
private sector, government agencies, and development partners. The terms of reference for the 
consultants include, but are not limited to, the following. 
1.  Solar Energy Development Specialist (Institutional) (team leader, 
international, 6 person-months) 
3.  The  solar  energy  development  specialist  (institutional)  and  team  leader  will  do  the 
following: 
(i)  Assist  the  Indian  Institute  of  Technology  (IIT)–Rajasthan  in  conceptualizing, 
setting up, and operationalizing the International Center for Application of Solar 
Energy Technologies (ICASET), and agencies of the state government of Gujarat 
in fully operating the solar school in the areas of solar photovoltaic and solar 
thermal energy, battery storage, integration of photovoltaic and solar thermal 
electric  power,  hybrid  solar  energy,  mini  and  micro  smart  grids,  and 
thermal-to-cooling and thermal-to-thermal technologies. 
(ii)  Assist IIT–Rajasthan in examining the feasibility of (a) capacity development, 
(b) technology adaptation, and (c) testing and standardization of both component 
and plant technologies for solar power generation and deployment, by ICASET. 
(iii)  Assist ICASET in becoming a subregional knowledge hub in South Asia and 
collaborating  with  the  proposed  Asia  Solar  Energy  Forum  (ASEF),  and  in 
developing a time-bound action plan for regional cooperation. 
(iv)  Assist ICASET and Gujarat government agencies in identifying the nature of 
human resources needed to successfully initiate and build on the above activities. 
(v)  Develop a viable business model and a 5-year budget and financing plan for the 
possible counterparts, e.g., the private sector (manufacturers, developers, and 
financing institutions), knowledge institutions, and other development partners 
participating in the ICASET concept. 
(vi)  On the basis of the budget requirement and financing plan, promote ICASET and 
Gujarat government agencies among counterparts elsewhere in India and abroad 
through  workshops,  consultation  meetings,  publications,  and  other  outreach 
activities. 
(vii)  Assist ICASET and Gujarat government agencies in developing memorandums 
of  understanding  with  academic  and  knowledge  institution  counterparts  for, 
among others, (a) joint research, (b) joint publication, and (c) exchange of faculty 
and students.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
(viii)  Assist ICASET and Gujarat government agencies in developing memorandums 
of understanding with private sector counterparts for, among others, (a) joint pilot 
project development; (b) joint testing of equipment; and (c) joint training for the 
private sector, ICASET, and Gujarat government agencies. 
(ix)  Identify  and  select  possible  counterparts  from  ICASET  and  the  Gujarat 
government agencies. 
(x)  Assist IIT–Rajasthan and other agencies in procuring the necessary equipment. 
(xi)  With the findings from the foregoing activities, provide input to the solar energy 
development specialist (engineering) for the detailed project report.  
2.  Solar Energy Development Coordinators (two national, 15 person-months 
each) 
4.  The solar energy development coordinators will assist the solar energy development 
specialist in all aspects of that specialist’s assignment. 
3.   Solar Energy Development Specialist (Engineer) (international, 
6 person-months) 
5.  For the benchmarking of the different photovoltaic solar technologies available, i.e., 
single-crystal silicon, polycrystalline silicon, thin-film, and multilayer solar cells, the proposed 
ICASET may set up a 1 megawatt (MW) solar plant employing different technologies. The plant 
will be integrated with smart alternating-current and direct-current micro grids for demonstration, 
research, and distribution of power to the grid. The power produced in the power plant the rest 
of the time would be sold to the neighboring grid and the revenue earned should partially 
support the running cost of the proposed center.  
(i)  With  the  input  from  the  solar  energy  development  specialist  (institutional), 
prepare a detailed project report on ICASET and its associated facilities including 
the 1 MW photovoltaic plant. 
(ii)  For the 1MW photovoltaic plant, assist ICASET in conducting due diligence work 
particularly  in  (a) detailing  the  solar  resource  assessment  and  environmental 
laboratory,  (b) detailing  the  selection  criteria  for  the  technology  provider, 
(c) assessing  grid  connectivity  and  regulatory  issues,  (d) listing  approvals 
required from government agencies to set up a solar plant, (e) detailing the 
agreement to be entered into with the technology provider, and (f) developing the 
modalities for the setting up of human resources development activities for this 
plant. 
4.  Solar Energy Engineer (national, 15 person-months) 
6.  The solar energy engineer will assist the solar energy development specialist in all 
aspects of the assignment of that specialist. 
5.   Private Sector Participation Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
7.  The private sector participation specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Promote  private  sector  participation  in  the  ICASET  and  Gujarat  solar  park 
projects, among others, using various kinds of knowledge platforms, e.g., ASEF.

(ii)  Conduct workshops to promote solar and smart-grid development, among others, 
in Gujarat and Rajatshan. 
(iii)  Assist  the  solar  energy  development  specialist  in  promoting  private  sector 
participation. 
6.  Capacity Development Coordinator (national, 15 person-months) 
8.  The capacity development coordinator will do the following: 
(i)  Assist  ICASET  and  the  Gujarat  government  agencies  in  developing  and 
implementing a capacity development program for various agencies in India, 
including  (a) state  governments,  (b) developers,  (c) manufacturers,  (d) power 
utilities, and (e) other agencies. 
(ii)  Develop  and  conduct  various  human  resources  exchange  programs  for 
professors, researchers, and students with universities, research institutes, and 
the private sector in developed countries in collaboration with ADB and other 
development partners. 
(iii)  Assist ICASET and Gujarat government agencies in disseminating knowledge on 
the outcome of the research and pilot-testing among the various stakeholders, 
and in providing a business model and sharing it with the relevant agencies and 
the private sector. 
(iv)  Coordinate with ASEF to turn ICASET into the regional knowledge hub of ASEF. 
(v)  Conduct workshops for knowledge sharing in India and abroad. 
(vi)  Assist the capacity development specialist in all aspects of that consultant’s 
assignment.  
7.  Solar Photovoltaic Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
9.  The solar photovoltaic specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Assess solar park development plan in Gujarat and Rajasthan, identify potential 
technical  issues  related  to  solar  photovoltaic  energy  in  the  operation  and 
maintenance of the solar parks, and propose solutions to these issues together 
with agencies to be designated by the state governments. 
(ii)  Conduct technology transfer activities in (a) the identification of key factors of 
efficiency losses in solar cells, (b) process optimization, and (c) development of 
non-vacuum-based deposition systems for large-area cells.  
(iii)  Assist agencies in developing and implementing a work program and budget in 
the area of solar photovoltaic energy development. 
(iv)  Assist the state government agencies in procuring the necessary equipment.  
(v)  Share  best-practice  methods  and  techniques  from  knowledge  institutions  in 
developed countries with the state government agencies. 
(vi)  Develop  and  conduct  various  human  resources  exchange  programs  for 
professors, researchers, and students with universities, research institutes, and 
the private sector in developed countries in collaboration with ADB and other 
development partners. 
8.  Smart-Grid Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
10.  The smart-grid specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Assess solar park development plan in Gujarat and Rajasthan, identify potential 
technical issues related to smart grids in the operation and maintenance of the

solar parks, and propose solutions to such issues together with agencies to be

C.  Reporting Requirements 
12.  The  consultants  will  work  under  the  direction  of  the  solar  energy  knowledge 
management specialist. The following reports will be produced for each assignment at key 
stages of the TA implementation: 
(i)  an inception report within the first calendar month; 
(ii)  a midterm report by the 12th calendar month; 
(iii)  a draft final report by the 22nd calendar month; and 
(iv)  a final report incorporating all the comments received, by the end of the 23rd 
calendar month. 
 
13.  Each consultant will submit to ADB five printed copies of each report and three digital 
copies of the final version of each report on CD-ROM, all in English.
